# utils.desirability.DCategorical { #spotdesirability.utils.desirability.DCategorical }

```python
utils.desirability.DCategorical(values, tol=None, missing=None)
```

Implements a desirability function for categorical inputs.

This class allows users to define desirability values for specific categorical inputs.

## Attributes {.doc-section .doc-section-attributes}

| Name    | Type             | Description                                                                                       |
|---------|------------------|---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| values  | [dict](`dict`)   | A dictionary where keys are category names (strings) and values are desirability scores (floats). |
| tol     | [float](`float`) | A tolerance value to replace desirability values of 0. Defaults to None.                          |
| missing | [float](`float`) | The value to use for missing inputs. Defaults to a non-informative value.                         |

## Functions {.doc-section .doc-section-functions}


Predicts the desirability values for the given categorical input data.


Plots the desirability function for the categorical inputs.

## References {.doc-section .doc-section-references}

This class is based on the 'desirability' package in R, see:
https://cran.r-project.org/package=desirability

## Examples {.doc-section .doc-section-examples}

```python
>>> from spotdesirability import DCategorical
>>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
# Define desirability values for categories
>>> values = {"A": 0.1, "B": 0.9, "C": 0.5}
# Create a DCategorical object
>>> dcat = DCategorical(values)
# Predict desirability for a list of categories
>>> inputs = ["A", "B", "C", "D"]
>>> desirability = dcat.predict(inputs)
>>> print(desirability)
[0.1 0.9 0.5 ValueError: Value 'D' not in allowed values: ['A', 'B', 'C']]
# Plot the desirability function
>>> dcat.plot()
```

### plot { #spotdesirability.utils.desirability.DCategorical.plot }

```python
utils.desirability.DCategorical.plot(
    non_inform=True,
    xlabel='Category',
    ylabel='Desirability',
    figsize=(10, 8),
    **kwargs,
)
```

Plots the desirability function for the categorical inputs.

#### Parameters {.doc-section .doc-section-parameters}

| Name       | Type                                                       | Description                                                                      | Default          |
|------------|------------------------------------------------------------|----------------------------------------------------------------------------------|------------------|
| non_inform | [bool](`bool`)                                             | Whether to display the non-informative value as a dashed line. Defaults to True. | `True`           |
| xlabel     | [str](`str`)                                               | Label for the x-axis. Defaults to "Category".                                    | `'Category'`     |
| ylabel     | [str](`str`)                                               | Label for the y-axis. Defaults to "Desirability".                                | `'Desirability'` |
| figsize    | [tuple](`tuple`)                                           | Size of the figure (width, height) in inches. Defaults to (10, 8).               | `(10, 8)`        |
| **kwargs   | [Dict](`typing.Dict`)\[[str](`str`), [Any](`typing.Any`)\] | Additional keyword arguments for the plot.                                       | `{}`             |

#### Examples {.doc-section .doc-section-examples}

```python
>>> from spotdesirability import DCategorical
>>> values = {"A": 0.1, "B": 0.9, "C": 0.5}
>>> dcat = DCategorical(values)
>>> dcat.plot()  # Default figure size
>>> dcat.plot(figsize=(12, 6))  # Custom figure size
```

### predict { #spotdesirability.utils.desirability.DCategorical.predict }

```python
utils.desirability.DCategorical.predict(newdata=None, missing=None)
```

Predicts the desirability values for the given categorical input data.

#### Parameters {.doc-section .doc-section-parameters}

| Name    | Type                                                | Description                                                                               | Default   |
|---------|-----------------------------------------------------|-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|-----------|
| newdata | [list](`list`) or [array](`array`) - [like](`like`) | A list or array of categorical inputs. If None, an empty array is used. Defaults to None. | `None`    |
| missing | [float](`float`)                                    | The value to use for missing inputs. Defaults to the object's `missing` attribute.        | `None`    |

#### Returns {.doc-section .doc-section-returns}

| Name   | Type                                        | Description                                 |
|--------|---------------------------------------------|---------------------------------------------|
|        | [numpy](`numpy`).[ndarray](`numpy.ndarray`) | The desirability values for the input data. |

#### Raises {.doc-section .doc-section-raises}

| Name   | Type                       | Description                                                  |
|--------|----------------------------|--------------------------------------------------------------|
|        | [ValueError](`ValueError`) | If a category in `newdata` is not in the allowed categories. |

#### Examples {.doc-section .doc-section-examples}

```python
>>> from spotdesirability import DCategorical
>>> values = {"A": 0.1, "B": 0.9, "C": 0.5}
>>> dcat = DCategorical(values)
>>> inputs = ["A", "B", "C"]
>>> desirability = dcat.predict(inputs)
>>> print(desirability)
[0.1 0.9 0.5]
```
